revision.text:
'''Articles of partnership''' is a voluntary [[contract]] between/among two or more persons to place their [[Capital (economics)|capital]], labor, and skills into business, with the understanding that there will be a sharing of the profits and losses between/among partners. Outside of North America, it is normally referred to simply as a '''partnership agreement'''.<ref>{{cite book|last=O'Sullivan |first=Arthur |authorlink=Arthur O'Sullivan (economist) |first2=Steven M. |last2=Sheffrin |title=Economics: Principles in Action |publisher=Pearson Prentice Hall |date=2003 |location=Upper Saddle River, New Jersey 07458 |pages=191 |isbn=0-13-063085-3}}</ref>
A partnership agreement is the written and legal agreement between/among business partners. It is always recommended but not essential for partners to have such an agreement.
==Articles of partnership== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2016}} Multiple sections are often included in articles of partnership, based on the circumstances: * the granting of the partner the rights to manage and administer the business or a specific department. * the authorization of a majority of partners to manage the affairs of the entire partnership. This is particularly common where there are numerous partners. * provisions to account for, annually, the property and debts of the business. * the forbidding of any partner to carry out business unrelated to the partnership. This is usually implied in articles of partnership. * the allowance of expelling partners who commit gross misconduct or becomes [[insolvent]], [[bankrupt]], etc. This is particularly common where there are numerous partners. * the submission of arguments to [[arbitration]]. * the allocation of business income and losses among partners.
==See also== * [[General partnership]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.lectlaw.com/def/a211.htm Articles of Partnership Defined & Explained] * [http://www.findlegalforms.com/articles/business/choosing-a-business-entity/partnership Article about choosing a Partnership as a business entity] * [http://softwarebillofrights.org/license.html Partnership agreement to constitute a Virtual Company]
[[Category:Business law]] [[Category:Legal documents]] [[Category:Partnerships]]

page.title: Best German Novels of the Twentieth Century

revision.text:
The '''Best German Novels of the Twentieth Century''' is a list of books compiled in 1999 by [[Literaturhaus München]] and [[Bertelsmann]], in which 99 prominent German authors, literary critics, and scholars of [[German language|German]] ranked the most significant German-language novels of the twentieth century.{{cite web|date=1999|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010607003313/http://www.literaturhaus.at/headlines/1999/01/142/ |archivedate=June 7, 2001 |title=Musils "Mann ohne Eigenschaften" ist "wichtigster Roman des Jahrhunderts"|url = http://www.literaturhaus.at/headlines/1999/01/142/|publisher= LiteraturHaus |language= German|accessdate= August 22, 2012}} The group brought together 33 experts from each of the three categories.Wolfgang Riedel, "Robert Musil: Der Mann ohne Eigenschaften" in ''Lektüren für das 21. Jahrhundert: Schlüsseltexte der deutschen Literatur von 1200 bis 1900'', ed. Dorothea Klein and Sabine M. Schneider, Würzburg: Königshausen & Neumann, 2000, {{ISBN|3-8260-1948-2}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ce_Bu0Zv-sEC&pg=PA265&lpg=PA265&dq=Musil+Mann+ohne+Eigenschaften+Thomas+Mann+Der+Zauberberg+Bertelsmann&source=bl&ots=wPtK1eVhkj&sig=hrY0uWUQb-7VPaR5SpYJZTVfRvs&hl=en&ei=6SzrTPKrHcfIceHSlbkP&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Musil%20Mann%20ohne%20Eigenschaften%20Thomas%20Mann%20Der%20Zauberberg%20Bertelsmann&f=false p. 265] {{de icon}} Each was allowed to name three books as having been the most important of the century. Cited by the group were five titles by both [[Franz Kafka]] and [[Arno Schmidt]], four by [[Robert Walser (writer)|Robert Walser]], and three by [[Thomas Mann]], [[Hermann Broch]], [[Anna Seghers]] and [[Joseph Roth]]. ==Top Ten== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !# !Year !Title !Author |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|1 |1930–43 |''[[The Man Without Qualities]]''
''Der Mann ohne Eigenschaften'' |{{sortname|Robert|Musil}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|2 |1925 |''[[The Trial]]''
''Der Process'' |{{sortname|Franz|Kafka}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|3 |1924 |''[[The Magic Mountain]]''
''Der Zauberberg'' |{{sortname|Thomas|Mann}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|4 |1929 |''[[Berlin Alexanderplatz]]'' |{{sortname|Alfred|Döblin}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|5 |1959 |''[[The Tin Drum]]''
''Die Blechtrommel'' |{{sortname|Günter|Grass}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|6 |1970-83 |''[[Anniversaries. From the Life of Gesine Cresspahl]]''
''Jahrestage 1-4: Aus dem Leben von Gesine Cresspahl'' |{{sortname|Uwe|Johnson}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|7 |1901 |''[[Buddenbrooks]]'' |{{sortname|Thomas|Mann}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|8 |1932 |''[[Radetzky March (novel)|Radetzky March]]''
''Radetzkymarsch'' |{{sortname|Joseph|Roth}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|9 |1926 |''[[The Castle (novel)|The Castle]]''
''Das Schloss'' |{{sortname|Franz|Kafka}} |- style="text-align:left;" |align="right"|10 |1947 |''[[Doctor Faustus (novel)|Doctor Faustus: The Life of the German Composer Adrian Leverkühn, Told by a Friend]]''
''Doktor Faustus: Das Leben des deutschen Tonsetzers Adrian Leverkühn, erzählt von einem Freunde'' |{{sortname|Thomas|Mann}} |} ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[[NRC's Best Dutch novels|''NRC'''s Best Dutch novels]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.derkanon.de/der-kanon-die-deutsche-literatur-romane/ Der Kanon] – article on the novels of the German literary canon {{de icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Best German Novels Of The Twentieth Century}} [[Category:German novels]] [[Category:Lists of novels]] [[Category:Top book lists]] [[Category:20th-century German novels| ]] [[Category:20th-century German literature]]

[[File:Emma Hart, later Lady Hamilton, George Romney, Rothschild collection, MFA Boston.jpg|thumbnail|George Romney, ''Portrait of Emma Hart''. Oil on canvas, c. 1784. Rothschild collection, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.<ref>[http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/rothschild_gift.pdf ''Gifts and promised gifts of the heirs of Bettina Looram de Rothschild''.] Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. [https://www.webcitation.org/6Wm9tyzPf?url=http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/rothschild_gift.pdf Archived here].</ref>]] '''Bettina "Nina" Burr''' (born c. 1946) is vice president of the board of trustees of the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]], to which she and other members of her family made a major donation of Rothschild family heirlooms that is known as The Rothschild Collection.
==Family== Burr was born Bettina Looram, around 1946.<ref name=artery>[http://artery.wbur.org/2015/02/23/mfa-rothschild-gift-nazi-stolen-art "MFA Receives Trove Of Art Seized By The Nazis."] Andrea Shea, TheArtery, 90.9wbur, 23 February 2015. Retrieved 3 March 2015.</ref> She is the daughter of [[Bettina Looram|Bettina Jemima Looram]] (née Rothschild) (1924–2012) and [[Matthew Looram|Matthew James Looram, Jr.]] (died 2004), an American diplomat, who married in 1943. She is the granddaughter of Baron and Baroness Alphonse and Clarice de Rothschild of the Vienna branch of the Rothschild family.<ref name=teleg>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/art-obituaries/9715373/Bettina-Looram.html "Bettina Looram".] ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 30 November 2012. Retrieved 3 March 2015.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-31699621 "The art rescued from Nazi looters."] BBC News Magazine, 3 March 2015. Retrieved 3 March 2015.</ref> Burr is a former teacher.<ref name=artery/>
==Museum of Fine Arts, Boston== Burr's association with the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, began after she became a tour guide there. She later helped to catalog the museum's [[Woodblock printing in Japan|Japanese woodblock prints]]. She first became an overseer, then in 2006 a trustee of the museum.<ref name=Blou>[http://blogs.artinfo.com/realcleararts/2015/02/22/mfas-gets-a-load-of-rothschild-loot/ "MFA’s Gets A Load of Rothschild Loot."] Judith H. Dobrzynski, ''BlouinArtInfo'', 22 February 2015. Retrieved 4 March 2015.</ref> She is now vice president of the board of trustees<ref>[http://philanthropynewsdigest.org/news/museum-of-fine-arts-boston-receives-gift-of-rothschild-collection Museum of Fine Arts, Boston Receives Gift of Rothschild Collection.] ''Philanthropy News Digest'', 25 February 2015. Retrieved 5 March 2015.</ref> and the Museum Representative to the [[Nagoya/Boston Museum of Fine Arts|Foundation for the Arts, Nagoya]].<ref>[http://www.mfa.org/annual-report-2014/trustees.html Board of Trustees July 2013-June 2014.] Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Retrieved 5 March 2015.</ref>
Some time after 2012, Burr and other heirs of Bettina Looram donated a collection of 186 objects, originally in the collection of Alphonse and Clarice de Rothschild, that were looted by the Nazis following the Austrian ''[[Anschluss]]'' with Germany in 1938. The museum has named the gift The Rothschild Collection. It includes, paintings, jewellery, prints and drawings, furniture, and books.<ref>[http://www.mfa.org/news/restoring-a-legacy-rothschild-family-treasures "Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Announces Major Gift from Rothschild Heirs, Including Family Treasures Recovered from Austria after WWII."] Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. 22 February 2015. Retrieved 3 March 2015.</ref> The Nazis seized nearly 3,500 items from the Vienna Rothschilds, many intended for Adolf Hitler's planned ''[[Führermuseum]]'' that would have been located in the Austrian city of Linz had it been built. The looted items were stored in the Austrian salt mines of [[Altaussee]] where they were discovered by the Allies after the war.<ref name=Bost/>
In order to export the bulk of the collection to the United States, where Clarice de Rothschild then lived, she was required to donate around 250 items to the Austrian government. These items were not recovered by the family until a change in Austrian law in 1999, long after Alphonse and Clarice de Rothschild had died. Many of the recovered items were then sold at auction in London in a sale that realised a record at that time of over £57m.<ref name=teleg/> The items donated to the Boston museum come mainly from the items recovered in 1999 that were not sold because they had particular family meaning. The jewellery included in the donation was never in Nazi hands because Clarice de Rothschild and her husband had been in London at the time of the ''Anschluss'' and she had had the jewellery with her.<ref name=Bost>[https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/2015/02/22/rothschild-heirs-donate-works-once-looted-nazis-mfa/64Axq5tuhcHrKxR4kVI0sI/story.html "Nazi-looted Rothschild art goes to MFA."] Malcolm Gay, ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', 23 February 2015. Retrieved 4 March 2015.</ref>
Among the items given to the Museum was [[George Romney (painter)|George Romney]]'s ''Portrait of Emma Hart'', later [[Lady Hamilton]], mistress of [[Lord Nelson]] and muse to Romney.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/23/arts/design/rothschild-family-treasures-find-a-resting-place-in-boston.html?_r=0 "Rothschild Family Treasures Find a Resting Place in Boston."] Judith H. Dobrzynski, ''[[The New York Times]]'', 22 February 2015. Retrieved 3 March 2015.</ref> Investigations have shown this to be the [[primary version]] of the work.<ref name=Blou/>
== See also == *[[Judith H. Dobrzynski]] *[[Nazi plunder]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *http://www.thepeerage.com/p19533.htm#i195329 *https://web.archive.org/web/20150402153915/http://archives.sps.edu/common/text.asp?Img=21735&Keyword=&Headline=&Author=&SearchMode=0
{{DEFAULTSORT:Burr, Bettina}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rothschild family]] [[Category:Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] [[Category:Trustees of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:1940s births]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Website | name = Capital Collections | url = [http://www.capitalcollections.org.uk/ Capital Collections] | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 9,138,034 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/capitalcollections.org.uk |title= Capitalcollections.org.uk Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> | website_type = [[image archive|image library]] | owner = [[Edinburgh Libraries]] | language = [[English language|English]] | launch date = February 2008 | current status = Active }} [[Image:Princes Street Edinburgh 1858.jpg|thumb|A photograph taken in 1858 by William Donaldson Clark showing Princes Street in Edinburgh, from Capital Collections online image library]] '''Capital Collections''' is Edinburgh Libraries' online image library. The project was initiated to provide greater access to some of the 100,000 images within its collections.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/12162/A-way-of-life-overtaken.3976167.jp | title=A Way of Life Overtaken by Modern Times }}</ref> The [[website]] was launched in February 2008 with an accompanying [[art exhibition|exhibition]], entitled “Edinburgh Past and Present”, featuring images chosen by personalities connected with the city.<ref name="Stars Choose Favourite Pictures">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/7263655.stm Stars Choose Favourite Pictures]</ref> Some of the celebrities who selected and commented on images from the collection included swimmer [[Kirsty Balfour]], impressionist [[Rory Bremner]], former [[Bishop of Edinburgh]] [[Richard Holloway]], and children’s author [[Aileen Paterson]]. Six years later, nearly 35,000 images have been digitised and more than 8000 images are available to view online.
==World Heritage Site== The [[digitisation]] project was part-funded by Edinburgh World Heritage Trust,<ref name="Capital Collections">[http://www.ewht.org.uk/Capital-Collections-Goes-Live.aspx Capital Collections] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704181917/http://www.ewht.org.uk/Capital-Collections-Goes-Live.aspx |date=July 4, 2009 }}</ref> to allow users access to the rare and unique material relating to the Old and New Towns of the UNESCO [[World Heritage Site]]. The website gives people all over the globe an educational tool to learn more about their family history and cultural roots.<ref name="Auld Reekie in New Light">[http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/scotland/Website-that-shows-Auld-Reekie.3818303.jp Auld Reekie in New Light]</ref>
The photographer involved with the project have the opportunity to take contemporary photographs of the city. The modern images compliment and provide comparisons with the early photographs of Edinburgh, as well as providing a valuable record of the changes occurring in the city.<ref name="The Scots Magazine">{{cite news | last=Simpson | first=Roddy | title=Edinburgh illustrated | publisher=[[D.C. Thomson & Co.]] | work=[[The Scots Magazine]] |date=January 2008}}</ref>
==Collections== The Special Collections within the departments of Central Library contain materials representing [[Edinburgh]] and [[Scotland| Scotland’s]] social, cultural and architectural heritage. They contain items of international importance in a variety of media, including paintings, Japanese prints, engravings and drawings. Capital Collections displays a particularly strong collection of early [[photography]], most notably including work by the founding fathers of modern photography [[Hill & Adamson]] <ref name="Edinburgh Evening News">{{cite news | last=Vallely | first=Joanna | title=Pioneers’ images in the public eye | publisher=[[The Scotsman Publications]] | work=[[Edinburgh Evening News]] | date=21 August 2007}}</ref> as well as lesser known pioneers, Archibald Burns, Thomas Keith and Thomas Begbie. Other artists of note include [[Walter Geikie]], [[John Kay (caricaturist)|John Kay]], [[Alexander Nasmyth]] and James Skene.
==New Developments== Capital Collections is also represented on [[Flickr]] giving further digital access to otherwise hard to reach resources. By adopting this alternative approach to digital media, the project is attempting to engage with new online audiences through the principles of [[photo sharing]] and [[user-generated content]].
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.capitalcollections.org.uk/ Official site] *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/ewht_capitalcollections/ Flickr page] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090304005807/http://www.ewht.org.uk/Home.aspx Edinburgh World Heritage] *[http://www.edinburgh.gov.uk/internet/Leisure/Libraries/Explore_your_library/Special_collections/CEC_special_collections_in_edinburgh_central_library/ Special Collections in Edinburgh Central Library]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
[[Category:Cultural heritage of Scotland]] [[Category:Library 2.0]] [[Category:Online archives]]

==Timezone effects==
When files are transferred across time zones and between Microsoft [[File Allocation Table|FAT]] and [[NTFS]] [[file system]]s, the timestamp displayed by the same file may change, so that identical files with different storage histories are deemed different by a comparer that requires the timestamps to match. The difference is an exact number of quarters of an hour up to 95 (same minutes modulo 15 and seconds) if the file was transported across zones; there is also a one-hour difference within a single zone caused by the transition between standard time and [[daylight saving time]] (DST). Some, but not all, file comparison and synchronisation software can be configured to ignore the DST and time-zone differences.<ref>Example: "Beyond Compare" help describes a user setting "timezone differences – ignores timestamp differences that are multiples of an exact hour."</ref> Software known to have daylight-saving compensation is marked in the [[#Aspects|Aspects]] table.

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2010}} A '''country code second-level domain''' is a [[second-level domain]] to a [[country code top-level domain]].{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} Such a domain may be reserved by a [[domain name registry]] for the registration of third-level domains, or assigned to a third party as a [[subdomain]].
Many country code domain registries implement domain name classes at the second level underneath their ccTLD, such as are present in the original generic [[top-level domain]]s <tt>com</tt>, <tt>net</tt>, and <tt>org</tt>, which were intended for commercial entities, network operators, and non-profit organizations, respectively.
Many countries implement additional classes. For example, the [[United Kingdom]] ([[.uk|uk]]) uses <tt>[[.co.uk|co.uk]]</tt> for commercial purposes and <tt>[[.ac.uk|ac.uk]]</tt> for academic registrants. Brazil ([[.br|br]]) has a high number of restricted second-level domains, 67 as of 2011;<ref>[http://registro.br/info/dpn.html Registro.br] 4 February 2011</ref> they range from <tt>com.br</tt> for commercial activities and <tt>vet.br</tt> for veterinarians to <tt>wiki.br</tt> for wikis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://registro.br/info/dpn.html|title=Registro.br|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Domain Name System]] *[[Private sub-domain registry]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://publicsuffix.org/ The Public Suffix List]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Country Code Second-Level Domain}} [[Category:Domain name system|Second-level domain]] [[Category:Second-level domains|*]]
